Application of nano-structured materials in anaerobic digestion: Current status and perspectives

g r a p h i c a l a b s t r a c t
Nanomaterial used in biogas process were classified and fully discussed. Effect of nanomaterials on biogas process is dosage dependent. Usage of multi-functional nanomaterials in biogas process is a promising area.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 1 February 2019 Received in revised form 10 April 2019 Accepted 24 April 2019 Available online 2 May 2019
Handling Editor: Y Liu
Keywords: Anaerobic digestion Nanomaterials Additives Biogas production Trace metals Contents
a b s t r a c t
Nanotechnology is gaining more attention in biotechnological applications as a research area with a huge potential. Nanoparticles (NPs) can influence the rate of anaerobic digestion (AD) as the nano-sized structures, with specific physicochemical properties, interact with substrate and microorganisms. The present work has classified the various types of additives used to improve the AD processes. Nanomaterials as new additives in AD process are classified into four categories: Zero-valent metallic NPs, Metal oxide NPs, Carbon based nanomaterials, and Multi-compound NPs. In the following, application of nanomaterials in AD process is reviewed and negative and positive effects of these materials on the AD process and subsequently biogas production rate are discussed. This study confirms that design and development of new nano-sized compounds can improve the performances of the AD processes.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Anaerobic digestion (AD) of organic waste streams has been a fast-growing green technology along with the increased environmental awareness to overcome energy and environmental challenges (Zidan sek et al., 2009). Clean fuel (biogas) is produced by the AD of different groups of organic wastes, i.e. animal manures, agriculture waste, forestry waste, sludge, food processing waste, and organic household waste (Angelidaki et al., 2003; Pieta et al., 2018). Four major steps are involved in complex AD process, i.e. hydrolysis, acidogenesis (primary fermentation), acetogenesis (secondary fermentation), and methanogenesis (Deublein and Steinhauser, 2011). Performance and efficiency of the AD process is highly dependent on various microorganisms involved in the digestion steps and also the type of substrate (Siddique andWahid, 2018). Biogas production rate could be enhanced by accelerating the slowest step known as the rate limiting step. The rate limiting step depends on the substrate type and its concentration, reactor temperature, configuration of the reactor and the organic loading rates. However, there is no fixed rate limiting step in all AD processes (Ganzoury and Allam, 2015). Many researchers reported that hydrolysis or solubilisation can be considered as the rate-limiting step in the AD of complex organic substrate, i.e. lignocellulosic substrate (Fernandes et al., 2009; Lynd et al., 2002; Rafique et al., 2010). On the other hand, in case of easily biodegradable substrates methanogenesis can be considered as the rate limiting step, since the methanogenic archaea have relatively slower growth rate compared microorganisms performing previous steps of the AD process (Lu et al., 2008). It is necessary to increase the overall reaction rate by accelerating the rate limiting steps.
In order to enhance the biogas production and assuring stability of the AD process, different strategies have been implemented. These methods include co-digestion with dissimilar substrates (to overcome obstacles as non-optimal C:N ratio or limited nutrients availability) (Luo and Angelidaki, 2013; Siddique and Wahid, 2018), pre-treatments of recalcitrant substrate (to release the biodegradable organic matter for microbial attack) (Dahunsi et al., 2017; Tsapekos et al., 2018b), modifying reactor configuration (Li et al., 2017), adjusting operation conditions (Leit~ao et al., 2006), and addition of organic/inorganic additives (to stimulate microbial activity) (Nzila, 2017; Romero-Güiza et al., 2016a, b). Additives used to enhance the biogas production in AD processes can be classified into organic and inorganic additives. Organic additives include green biomass, microbial cultures, and enzymes (Angelidaki et al., 2018; Romero-Güiza et al., 2016a, b). Inorganic additives can be sub-divided into macro-nutrients, micro-nutrients, and carbonous materials (Dang et al., 2016). The macro-nutrients, i.e. phosphorus (P), nitrogen (N), sulfur (S) are added to feedstock of AD process in the form of salts to improve the system buffer capacity. Micronutrients, i.e. nickel (Ni), cobalt (Co), iron (Fe), molybdenum
(Mo), etc., are crucial constituents of co-factors and enzymes in numerous biological reactions involved in AD and their addition to anaerobic bioreactors has been proven to stimulate the performance of biogas production reactors (Demirel and Scherer, 2011; Gustavsson et al., 2013). These trace elements can be added to AD process in the form of salts, pure metal/metal oxides (bulk material), and recently in the form of nano-structured materials. Significant research efforts have been focused on adding carbonous materials, as conductive non-biological materials, to anaerobic digesters. Results from these studies revealed that carbonous materials (such as granular activated carbon, biochar, graphite, carbonbased nano materials) can act as an electron conduit for direct interspecies electron transfer (DIET) between syntrophic microorganisms and enhance the biomethane yield and rate (Barua and Dhar, 2017; Martins et al., 2018; Salvador et al., 2017). The additives used in AD processes can be summarized as shown in Fig. 1. Researchers have used the inorganic additives in the form of nanostructured materials to study the catalytic effect of nanomaterials on the AD process. Furthermore, nanomaterials have been used in anaerobic treatment processes to enhance the microbial degradation of recalcitrant pollutants, such as halogenated pollutants, phenolic compounds, aromatic compounds, etc. (Cervantes et al., 2016; Li et al., 2016a,b; Pat-Espadas et al., 2016).
Nano-sized materials (1e100 nm) as additive could have negative or positive effect on AD processes. Due to the unique thermal, mechanical, structural properties and high specific area of nanoscale materials, nanotechnology has become a growing technology in environmental, medical, and chemical industries (Ünşar and Perendeci, 2018). These unique properties (that are attributed to very small size) of nanomaterials motivate researchers to investigate the effects of these materials on diverse biological applications such as AD process to develop the green energy production.
This review presents an overview of the recent attempts in the application of nanomaterials in the AD due to their capacity to
improve the performance of this process.

sections.heading: 2. Application of nanomaterials in anaerobic digestion
sections.text: Nanomaterials, with any external dimension in the size range from approximately 1-100 nm, have extensively been used in many applications including energy, agriculture, coating, catalysts, automotive, sensors, food products, and environmental processes and researches are continued to find new applications (Keller et al., 2013; Zhou et al., 2011). Nanomaterials have excellent physicochemical properties (i.e. size, specific surface area, surface structure, solubility, catalytic properties) which make them to be useful in wide applications (Hussein, 2015). As particle size decreases, the surface-to-volume ratio increases. The properties of nanoscale material can be totally different from their corresponding properties in either bulk form or as part of larger scale entities (Krol et al., 2012). Nanomaterials possess promoted mobility in environmental media, so they have high potential to be as a new functional material and device with unique activity for biological systems (Abdelsalam et al., 2016; Lu et al., 2016). Nanomaterials have an important property in interaction with biological systems since they are able to penetrate cell membranes, thus facilitating the interaction with the immune system (Huangfu et al., 2018; LunadelRisco et al., 2011). The positive effects of nanomaterials are achieved by specific characteristics as high surface area, high reactivity, high specificity (Abdelsalam et al., 2016). It has been proved that supplementation of micro-nutrients in the form of nanoparticles improved the AD performance (Casals et al., 2014). The slow dissolve of NPs facilitates the bioavailability in the AD media and enhances the enzymatic activity (Abdelsalam et al., 2017a,b). On the other hand, enzymatic adsorption onto NPs will cause conformational transitions, accompanied by the inhibition or enhancement of enzyme activity depending on concentration (Chen et al., 2017). All nanomaterials used in AD processes can be categorized in four groups, i.e. zero valent metallic NPs, metal oxide NPs, carbonous nanomaterials, and multi-compound NPs (Fig. 2). A gap of knowledge in the design and application of multi-compound NPs with predetermined properties exists. In the following, the applications of various types of NPs are reviewed based on the mentioned classification.

sections.heading: 2.1. Zero valent metallic nanoparticles
sections.text:
Nanoscale zero valent metals (NZVMs), i.e. Fe, Ni, Cu, Co, Ag, Au, etc., with significant strong chemical reducibility, high efficiency,
and large specific surface have the most promising applications in environmental processes compared to zero valent metals (ZVMs) (Li et al., 2016a,b). In fact, the percentage of atoms located at the surface of particle increases with the decrease in particle size regarding the mass of particle, which can raise the tendency to adsorb, interact, and react with other atoms, molecules, and complexes (Crane and Scott, 2012). Table 1 summarizes the efforts of zero valent NPs reported in the literature. As mentioned before, the AD is carried out by different groups of microorganisms. The flow of electrons within these communities governs the occurrence of reactions and their rates (Cheng and Call, 2016). Interaction between acetogenesis and methanogenesis, mediated by interspecies electron transfer between syntrophic bacteria and methanogenic archaea plays a vital role in improving the AD efficiency (Stams and Plugge, 2009). Mediated interspecies electron transfer (MIET) based on the exchange of metabolites (i.e. H2, formate) between two microorganisms is one of the earliest discovered mechanisms of external electron transfer (Storck et al., 2016). In MIET, the electron-donatingmicroorganism reduces protons to hydrogen and the electron-accepting microorganism oxidizes the hydrogen with the reduction of an electron acceptor (Sieber et al., 2012). MIET is feasible only at low enough concentrations of H2/formate metabolites due to the thermodynamic constraints (Cruz Viggi et al., 2014). Intrinsically, MIET via diffusive carriers (i.e. H2 and formate) is a slow mechanism due to slow diffusion rate of metabolites in the reaction media, (Kato et al., 2012). Recently, researchers showed that DIET via electrically conductive materials, i.e. nano zero valent iron (NZVI) and carbonous materials, energetically havemore advantageous overMIET, because DIET does not require the multiple enzymatic steps to produce hydrogen as an electron carrier (Zhao et al., 2015). Addition of electrically conductive materials, to anaerobic digesters is an engineered approach to stimulate DIET and subsequently promote biogas production.
NZVI has been widely investigated as a nanoscale zero valent metallic additive in the field of biogas production. Suanon et al. (2017) showed that the application of 100mg/L NZVI (160 nm) in batch bio-digesters enhanced the methane production from sewage sludge up to 25.2%. The results were in accordance with previous findings reported in elsewhere (Su et al., 2013; Xu et al., 2004). Su et al. (2013) reported the promotion of biogas and methane production up to 30.4% and 40.4%, respectively, by addition of 0.1wt% NZVI (10mg/L) to the AD process of sewage sludge during 17 days of batch experiment.
The effects of 9 nm NZVI NPs on the methanogenic archaea during the AD of raw manure (feces and urine) in a batch mode were also investigated by Abdelsalam et al. (2017a, b). They reported that addition of 20mg/L of NZVI NPs to bio-digester under mesophilic temperature stimulates the methanogenic archaea and increases its activity and subsequently increasing biogas and methane production up to 45 and 59%, respectively.
On the contrary, Yang et al. (2013) showed that NZVI NPs (55 nm) with a concentration of 1mM (56mg/L) inhibited methanogenesis more than 20% during the AD of sludge. They reported that the inhibition was due to the disruption of cell integrity in exposure to NZVI NPs. In addition, rapid H2 production was observed in the presence of NZVI NPs under anaerobic conditions (Fe þ 2H2O / Fe2þ þ H2 þ 2OH ) as reported by Liu et al. (2006). The produced H2 takes part in bacterially controlled hydrogenotrophic process (i.e., 2CO2 þ 4H2/ CH3COOH þ 2H2O) in AD. Addition of 30mM (1680mg/L) of NZVI to bio-digester during AD process caused a significant increase of soluble COD (due to microorganism cell disruption) and volatile fatty acids in the bioreactor medium, resulting in 69% decrease of methane production.
Abelsalam et al. (2016)also declared that introducing 1mg/L Co NPs (28 nm), 2mg/L Ni NPs (17 nm) or 20mg/L NZVI (9 nm) to the AD process of raw manure increase the biogas yield by 50%, 70%, and 80% compared to controlled condition, respectively. The yield of methane increased significantly by 67%, 117%, and 100% more than the methane yield of the controlled condition, respectively. Ni, Co, and NZVI NPs applied in this study improved various biological processes involved in biogas and methane production. This observation is in accordance with the results obtained by Gustavsson et al. (2013) who stated that Ni and Co concentrations in digester substrates, organic matters, promote biogas production by increasing methane production and making the AD process stable.
Wang et al. (2016) investigated the effects of NZVI (128 nm) and zero valent Ag (170 nm) NPs on methane production during the AD of waste activated sludge under mesophilic conditions. Based on their results, introducing 10mg/g total suspended solid (TSS) NZVI to the digester increased the methane production more than 120%, while introducing 500mg/g TSS zero valent Ag NPs produced 26.48% lower amounts of methane. The results indicated that the number of microorganisms and activity of key enzymes, such as protease, acetate kinase and coenzyme F420, are boosted by adding low concentration of NZVI NPs, but high concentration of zero valent Ag NPs inhibits the microbial growth and activity. Microbial analysis showed that the population of active bacteria and archaea (i.e. a-proteobacteria, b-Proteobacteria, bacteroidetes and methanosaeta) is increased by introducing 10mg/g of TSS NZVI.
Abdelsalam et al. (2017a, b) studied the effect of Ni and Co NPs (0.5, 1, and 2mg/L) on the AD of manure at mesophilic conditions. They showed that the addition of the examined NPs led to reduction of lag phase and increase of biogas and methane production
rates. The results revealed that Ni and Co NPs have strong biostimulating effects on the methanogenic activity. The cumulative amount of biogas and methane production were directly proportional to the concentration of Ni NPs up to 2mg/L the results confirmed that the addition of 0.5, 1 and 2mg/L Ni NPs and 1mg/L NiCl2 to the substrate increased the biogas production by 46, 72, 74 and 44%, respectively. These results are in agreement with those obtained by Demirel and Scherer (2011) who stated that the stimulatory concentrations of Ni for batch cultures of methanogens were in the range of 0.012e5mg/L. Introducing 0.5mg/L Co, 1mg/L of Co NPs, and 1mg/L of CoCl2 increased the biogas production up to 36, 64, and 32% higher than the volume of biogas produced under controlled condition, respectively. Enhancement of biogas and methane production using 1mg/L Co NPs was in accordance with the results obtained by Demirel and Scherer (2011) and Feng et al. (2010) who reported that Co is an important metal for methanogenesis as it acts as metallic enzyme activator. On the other hand, the addition of Co NPs with concentration more than 1mg/L, i.e. 2mg/L, showed a toxicity effect on the methanogenic archaea which decreased 5% of biogas production and 12.7% of methane, compared to the controlled assays, during 50 days of AD process. The undesired effect of 2mg/L Co NPs on biogas and methane production are in agreement with those reported by Facchin et al. (2013) declaring that the supplementation of excess metals could have a negative effect on acetoclastic methanogenesis or on other metabolic pathways of an AD process.
Tsapekos et al. (2018a) investigated the effect of Ni NPs (<100 nm) on anaerobic digestion of sewage sludge in batch and continuous mode at thermophilic condition. Results showed that 5 mgNi-NPs/kgVS in the presence of nitrilotriacetic acid (NTA) as
chelating agent enhanced themethane yield up to 10% compared to the control sample in batch mode. The Ni NPs also boosted the methane yield of continuous digester up to 8%.
García et al. (2012) investigated the effects of Ag (30 nm) and Au (20 nm) NPs on activity of key microorganisms such as ordinary heterotrophic organisms, ammonia oxidizing bacteria, and other anaerobic bacteria presented in municipal wastewater. Based on their results, Ag NPs had a toxicity effect and inhibited the biogas production by 33e50%, whereas Au NPs showed zero or slight inhibition for all kind of tested substrates.
Gitipour et al. (2016) stabilized Ag NPs with different capping agents at concentrations of 0.5, 1, 5, and 100mg/L and used them for AD of biosolids from aWWTP. Based on their results, negatively charged citrate-coated NPs (citrate-Ag NPs) and minimally charged polyvinylpyrrolidone coated Ag NPs (PVPeAg NPs) showed no toxicity and inhibitory effects on biogas production at any concentration. In the case of citrate-Ag NPs, the lack of toxicity might be due to aggregation and subsequent settling which can lower the bioavailability of NPs for the microbiome. The minimum surface charge on PVP-Ag NPs may have resulted in lower attraction between the NPs and the negatively charged bacterial membrane, exhibiting low toxicity. Relatively high concentration (i.e. 100mg/L) of positively charged branched polyethyleneimine coated Ag NPs (BPEI-Ag NPs) demonstrates elevated toxicity, similar in magnitude to that of Agþ ion, in comparison to PVP-Ag NPs and the anionic citrate-Ag NPs.
Ünşar et al. (2016) also investigated short-term, i.e. 72 h, and long-term, i.e. 48 days, inhibition effects of 20e40 nm Ag NPs on the AD of waste activated sludge (WAS). They observed that Ag did not cause significant impacts on AD process during short-term exposure of NPs. In the long-term test, the introduction of Ag NPs at the highest dosage (i.e. 500mg/gTS) caused 12.1% decrease in the methane production. Slow and long term silver release fromAg NPs dissolution cause inhibition of methane production after. Release of silver ions after long-term AD creates imposes antibacterial effects by making defects in cell membranes or causing enzyme inactivation or protein dephosphorylation (Prabhu and Poulose, 2012).
Inhibitory effects of Ag, Cu and Fe NPs on acetoclastic and hydrogenotrophic methanogenic activities of anaerobic granular sludge were investigated by Gonzalez-Estrella et al. (2013). Their results revealed that 1500mg/L of Cu NPs (40e60 nm) was highly inhibitory to both acetoclastic and hydrogenotrophic methanogens due to the release of toxic Cu2þ ions caused by corrosion and dissolution of the NPs. In contrary, methanogens were not inhibited when exposed to high concentrations (1500mg/L) of Ag and Fe NPs. This is in agreement with the results of other researches (García et al., 2012; Yang et al., 2012) reported that high concentrations of Ag NPs did not cause methanogenic inhibition. Although Ag is toxic to a number of microorganisms, relatively high concentrations of Ag NPs (40e43mg/L) did not cause methanogenic inhibition. Oxysulfidation and sulfidation of Ag NPs in anaerobic media caused precipitation of Ag NPs in the form of AgS, a non-toxic form of Ag (Choi et al., 2009). Therefore, the sulfide concentration in the various studies should be expected to have a considerable effect on the inhibitory potential of the Ag NPs.
Cervantes et al. (2016) studied the catalytic effect of bimetallic alloys of PdeCu NPs on microbial reduction of p-nitrophenol (PNP) to p-aminophenol (PAP). Results showed that addition of 20mg/L of PdeCu NPs to methanogenic sludge incubations caused increasing threefold reduction rate of PNP with negligible accumulation of toxic intermediates compared with sludge incubations lacking metallic NPs. Metallic NPs facilitate transfer of reducing equivalents derived from lactate/ethanol fermentation towards the nitro group in PNP.
Pat-Espadas (2016)investigated the effect of Pd NPs on
biotransformation of two recalcitrant halogenated pollutants, 3- chloro-nitrobenzene (3-CNB) and iopromide (IOP), in anaerobic granular sludge media in batch and continuous upflow anaerobic sludge blanket (UASB) reactors. Pd-immobilized sludge increased removal efficiency of IOP and 3-CNB up to 80% and 100%, respectively, compared with the control (not exposed to Pd) indicating Pd NPs has an important catalytic effect during the biotransformation of IOP. Pd-enreached sludge act as solid-phase redox mediators in the biotransformation of recalcitrant pollutants. In the case of these halogenated compounds, that are highly resistant to oxidation, Pd NPs can help to achieve dehalogenation since this NPs is able to convert hydrogen gas to adsorbed atomic hydrogen which is a powerful reducing agent that reacts with oxidized functional groups under methanogenic conditions.

sections.heading: 2.2. Metal oxide nanoparticles
sections.text:
Metal oxide NPs play a very important role in many areas of chemistry, physics and materials science (Rodríguez and Fern andez-García, 2007). Metal oxide NPs can exhibit unique physical and chemical properties due to their small sizes and high density of corner or edge surface sites (Fern andez-García and Rodriguez, 2011). There are numerous types of metal oxide NPs such as ZnO, CuO, TiO2, MgO, NiO, Fe2O3 nanoparticles etc. (Noguera, 1996). In the developing field of nanotechnology, it is tried to benefit from metal oxide NPs in process of biogas production. From this point of view, researchers have evaluated the impacts of metal oxide NPs on the efficiency of AD processes (Table 2).
Wang et al. (2016) investigated the impacts of metal oxide NPs (i.e. Fe2O3, MgO) on the AD of WAS in dosages up to 500 mg/g TSS. The authors reported that the supplementation of 100mg/g TSS Fe2O3 NPs increased 117% the methane production rate, while 500mg/g TSS MgO NPs produced 98.92% lower amounts of methane. These results indicated that number of microorganisms and enzymatic activity is increased by introducing low concentrations of Fe2O3 NPs, but high concentrations of MgO NPs had an inhibitory effect. Measuring lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) concentration, as a cell-membrane damage indicator, showed that LDH concentration in case of adding 500mg/g TSS MgO NPs was significantly higher than that in the reactor containing 100mg/g TSS Fe2O3 NPs. This shows that high concentrations of MgO NPs probably damage cell membranes and release more LDH contents. Lower concentration of MgO NPs ( 100 mg/g TSS) did not cause any beneficial or inhibitory effect on biogas production rate. Abdelsalam et al. (2017a, b) studied the effects of Fe3O4 magnetic NPs on the methanogens during the AD of raw manure. Their research revealed that 20mg/L Fe3O4 NPs at 37 C stimulated the activity of methanogenic populations and subsequently, led to higher methane production rate. In addition, Fe3O4magnetic NPs provided a uniform distribution of Fe ions in the media, which maintained a sustainable supply of Fe ions in the digester.
Ali et al. also studied the effects of Fe3O4 NPs (15e22 nm) on the AD of municipal solid waste under mesophilic conditions (Ali et al., 2017). Results showed that Fe3O4 NPs caused the enhancement of methane production rate by stimulating the enzymatic activities of methanogens up to 117%. In addition, the presence of NPs ensured a uniform distribution of iron ions in the solution, which maintained a sustainable supply of Fe ions in the reactor. The addition of 50 and 75mg/L of NPs were more effective in improving the methane production rate. In contrast, higher concentrations (i.e. 100 and 125mg/L) reduced the methane production. Ali et al. concluded that the NPs guaranteed a uniform distribution of iron ions in the media, which maintained a sustainable supply in the aqueous media. Abelsalam et al. (2017a, b) who stated that iron and iron oxide NPs can improve the performance of bioreactors due to the graduate release of Feþ2/Feþ3 ions. Regarding the metabolism of microorganisms, iron element can enhance activities of methanogenic archaea as reported by Qiang et al. (2012). Also, Su et al. (2013)and Liu et al. (2015) concluded that the addition of iron-based NPs could provide resistance against the formation of hydrogen sulfide (H2S) and increased stability by pH buffering. Furthermore, the use of Fe3O4 NPs has been associated with facilitation of DIET in syntrophic methanogenesis. Such an effect is highly increased when Fe3O4 is utilized in nanoscale range, because of numerous active sites that nano-scale materials provide (Ali et al., 2017).
Casals et al. (2014) controlled the dosage of Fe3þ/Fe2þ ions during an AD process by size and surface-state engineering of Fe3O4 NPs. Results showed that the Fe3O4 NPs (100 ppm of 7 nm) dispersed in an anaerobic waste treatment reactor and gradually
dissolved in form of Fe3þ/Fe2þ ions, acting as effective elements. This strategy keeps the concentration of Fe3þ/Fe2þ ions in optimal range during the AD process and boost the bacterial activity over an extended time leading to 180% higher biogas production rate during 50 days of process. Nguyen et al. (2015) studied the effect of CeO2 and ZnO NPs on the AD of sludge in an UASB. Results showed that adding NPs at low concentration (i.e. 10mg/L, of CeO2) boosted the performance of biogas reactor about 11% as compared with the controlled experiment. In contrast, the bacterial toxicity assays showed that higher concentrations of NPs are toxic to microbiome, reducing the biogas production rate. Adding CeO2 NPs, above 100mg/L, resulted in decrease of biogas production rate. The reductions of the total biogas production volume due to adding CeO2 NPs at 100, 500, and 1000mg/L were 32.2%, 32.3%, and 35.1%, respectively. Also, the authors reported that inhibition of biogas production with ZnO NPs is dosage dependent. At a low
concentration of ZnO NPs, 10mg/L, the reduction in biogas volume was 8.4% and the biogas inhibition reached to 65.3% in the presence of 1000mg/L of ZnO NPs.
García et al. (2012) studied the effect of TiO2, and CeO2 NPs on the activity of microorganisms presented in WWTP. They reported that 640mg/L CeO2 inhibited the biogas production up to 100%, whereas TiO2 NPs showed zero or slight inhibition for all tested biomasses at mesophilic temperature. Introducing TiO2 NPs had a slightly positive effect (10% increases) on the biogas production in thermophilic conditions. Likewise, CeO2 NPs caused an intense inhibition (90%) at thermophilic conditions. In another work, Zheng et al. (2015) stated that TiO2 NPs had no significant impact on hydrolysis, acidification, and methane production during the AD of sludge, even at high concentrations (i.e. 150mg/g TSS), both in short- and long-term exposure.
Ambuchi et al. (2016) investigated the role of iron oxide NPs (Fe2O3) in the enhancement of the AD performance of granular activated sludge. The results showed that Fe2O3 NPs at a concentration of 750mg/L caused faster utilization of substrate and biogas production rates than the controlled condition. In their study, microbial community analysis revealed the role of Anaerolineaceae and Longilinea bacteria, predominant bacterial genera in the biodegradation process, could have highly been boosted by NPs.
The influence of ZnO NPs on the methane production rate during the AD of waste activated sludge was investigated by Mu et al. (2011). Their results indicated that 1 mg/g-TSS of ZnO NPs had no positive or negative effect on the methane production rate, while 30 and 150 mg/g-TSS of ZnO NPs caused 18.3% and 75.1% inhibition, respectively. The toxic effect of ZnO NPs on themethane production rate was mainly attributed to the release of Zn2þ ion, which inhibited the activities of protease, acetate kinase, and coenzyme F420, leading to inhibition of hydrolysis and methanation steps (Zheng et al., 2015).
Zhang et al. (2017) declared that addition of ZnO nanomaterials during the AD of activated sludge increased the accumulation of VFAs. The promoted VFAs accumulation in the presence of ZnO nanomaterials was due to the slow production and slower consumption rates of VFAs during the AD process. The decrease of production rate of VFAs was mainly contributed to the inhibition of protein hydrolysis by Zn2þ ions. Decrease in biogas and methane production was in agreement with the results obtained by Mu and Chen (2011) that proved the slow consumption of VFAs in the presence of ZnO nanomaterials.
Luna-del Risco et al. (2011) investigated the effects of various concentrations of bulk and nano-sized CuO and ZnO powder on the biogas production rate during the AD of cattle manure at 36 C. Their results showed that bulk and nano-size powder at concentrations higher than 120 and 15mg/L for CuO and 240 and 120mg/L for ZnO could remarkably inhibit the biogas production rate. Similar to the work of Mu et al. (2011), the inhibition of biogas and methane production in the presence of these NPs was attributed to the bioavailable portion of the existed metal. The results showed that the most toxic compounds to anaerobic microorganisms were CuO NPs (30 nm), ZnO NPs (50e70 nm), bulk ZnO and bulk CuO, respectively. It is noteworthy that the biogas production rate increased in the last days of experiment, indicating that the anaerobic bacteria were adapted to the NPs and were able to tolerate in such an environment.
Ünşar et al. (2016) investigated inhibition impacts of CuO and CeO2 NPs on the AD of WAS in case of short-term and long-term exposure. CuO NPs had the most toxic effect on microorganisms during the AD process. Increase of CuO NPs concentration, from 11 to 1100mg/L, increased the inhibition levels from 5.8 to 84.0%. Based on their results, CeO2 NPs did not cause intense effects on the AD process compared to CuO NPs. Long-term exposure of 1100mg/
L of CeO2 NPs caused 9.2% increase in the methane production rate. Furthermore, the hydrolysis rate constant (kH) of WAS in all tests of CeO2 NPs was 0.0277 d 1, while the kH of WAS in the presence of high concentration of CuO NPs was 0.0016 d 1. The toxic effect of CuO NPs could be attributed to their heavy metal characteristics.
Gonzalez-Estrella et al. (2013) investigated the inhibitory effect of inorganic oxide NPs (i.e. Al2O3, CeO2, CuO, ZnO, Fe2O3, Mn2O3, SiO2, TiO2) on acetoclastic and hydrogenotrophic methanogenic activities in the AD of granular sludge. The results revealed that CuO and ZnO NPs are highly inhibitory to activity of acetoclastic and hydrogenotrophic methanogens. 62 and 68mg/L of CuO NPs and 87 and 250mg/L of ZnO NPs caused 50% inhibition towards acetoclastic and hydrogenotrophic methanogens, respectively. The inhibition is mainly due to the release of toxic Cu2þ and Zn2þ ions caused by corrosion and dissolution of the NPs. In contrary, methanogens were not inhibited when exposed to high concentrations (1500mg/L) of Al2O3, CeO2, Mn2O3, Fe2O3, SiO2, and TiO2 NPs, suggesting that anaerobic treatment processes could tolerate high concentrations of these types of NPs.
The number of reports concerning the toxicity of NPs indicate that addition of natural organic matter (NOM) to the different NPs resulted in lower toxicity to the majority of the organisms (Grillo et al., 2015). NOM could form complexes with released metal ions and lowering their bioavailability in the media, hence lowering the toxicity (Gao et al., 2012). In the other scenario the surface charge of NPs could be changed due to bonding with the NOM, changing the interaction with other compounds (Romanello and Cortalezzi, 2013). Chen et al. (2011) reported using 10mg/L of humic acids (HA), as a model for NOM, in contaminated water with hazardous oxidized pollutants significantly decreased toxicity of NZVI towards gram-negative Escherichia coli and gram-positive Bacillus subtilis. The TEM images showed that the surface of NZVI and microorganisms covered by NOM. This decreased the zeta potential of NZVI from 30 to 45 mV and caused electrosteric hindrance to minimize direct contact with microorganisms, which decreased cell membrane destruction. Alvarez and Cervantes (2012) investigated the effect of bare and coated g-Al2O3 NPs with HA on specific methanogenic activity in an anaerobic granular sludge consortium. Their results revealed that HA-coated g-Al2O3 NPs mitigated the toxicological effects of g-Al2O3 NPs on methanogenic microorganisms. The HA-coated NPs could enhance Al3þ sorption, thus decreasing the toxicological effects of this ion.

sections.heading: 2.3. Carbon based nanomaterials
sections.text:
The carbon based nanostructures can be found at different types such as graphene, diamond, nanotube and nanofibers. They have high surface area for the deposition of conducting polymer and metal/metal oxide NPs, which facilitate the efficient ion diffusion. Furthermore, they have small dimensions, high chemical stability, high thermal conductivity and low resistivity (Bose et al., 2012). Table 3 summarizes the researches regarding the applications of carbon based nanostructures in the AD process.
The effect of graphene as a highly conductive carbon based nanomaterial on the efficiency of AD process of ethanol, as a key intermediate product, was studied by Lin et al. (2017). They observed that, the addition of 1.0 g/L graphene resulted in an enhancement of 25% in methane yield and 19.5% in biogas production rate. Interspecies electron transfer between bacteria and archaea plays a vital role in promoting the efficiency of AD processes. Microbial analysis revealed that electrogenic bacteria of Geobacter and Pseudomonas along with archaea Methanobacterium and Methanospirillum might participate in DIET. Graphene-based DIET can sustain higher electron transfer flux than conventional hydrogen transfer because of high electrical conductivity of

graphene along with its high surface area. The lag phase time and peak time decreased in the presence of graphene. Furthermore, the degradation rate of ethanol was simultaneously enhanced by adding graphene, which is possibly due to the high electrical conductivity and specific surface area of graphene. On the other hand, methane yield slightly decreased with increasing the graphene concentration to 2.0 g/L. This was probably due to the microbial inhibition effect caused by high concentration of graphene, indicating that cytotoxicity could become an undesired phenomenon when applying carbonous nanomaterials in AD. Cytotoxicity of carbon nano structures (i.e. graphene and CNT) to microorganisms has been presented using different microbial strains such as Escherichia coli (Liu et al., 2011).
Tian et al. (2017) studied short-term and long-term effects of graphene on AD processes using pure glucose as substrate at 35 C. Results showed that short-term exposure of graphene with concentration of 30 and 120mg/L had significantly positive effects on methane production rate, which increased by 17.0% and 51.4%, respectively. However, long-term exposure to graphene at 120mg/ L showed slight inhibition of methanogen at ambient temperature (10e20 C). High concentration of graphene causes microbial inhibition, indicating that cytotoxicity could become an adverse effect when using nanomaterials in AD processes. They concluded that acetate-consuming methanogenesis was enhanced by adding graphene to the AD process at mesophilic conditions. Furthermore, Geobacter enrichment was observed with graphene, suggesting that the DIET might be promoted. This conclusion is due to the fact that DIET between Geobacter species and Methanosaeta or Methanosarcina species is recognized as an effective form of syntrophy in methanogenic communities (Bueno-L opez et al., 2018; Dub e and Guiot, 2015). Graphene act as electric cunduits between Methanosaeta and Geobacter promoting DIET process. Then, Methanosaeta consume electrons produced from the oxidation of propionate or butyrate to acetate (Zhao et al., 2016).
Li et al. (2015) reported that the electrical conductivity of sludge was enhanced in the presence of single wall carbon nanotubes (SWCNT) at mesophilic temperature, which might promote DIET among fermentative bacteria and methanogens in the AD process. Thus, it is hypothesized that materials with higher conductivity could play a more significant role in promoting the DIET. They showed that introducing 1000mg/L of SWCNT to the sludge for 180 h had no effect on cumulative methane production rate in comparison to the controlled experiment, while SWCNT dosing caused faster substrate utilization and methane production rate.
In another research, Yan et al. (2017) studied the effects of single wall carbon nanotubes SWCNT, as a conductive material, on the AD of glucose. They also found that conductive materials such as
SWCNT could promote the start-up of thermophilic process. Their results showed that the methane production rate in conductive materials supplemented reactors was almost 100% higher than the controlled reactors. The promoted biogas production rate was also related to the establishment of DIET.
Ambuchi et al. (2016) investigated the role of multi wall carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) in enhancing the AD performance of granular activated sludge. They showed that MWCNTs at the concentration of 1500mg/L facilitated the utilization of substrate and biogas production rate. This finding suggests that MWCNTs could be a good enhancer of direct interspecies electron transfer leading to increased biogas production rate.
Nyberg et al. (2008) studied the effect of fullerene (C60) on the AD of wastewater sludge. Their findings suggest that C60 fullerenes have no significant effect on the anaerobic community during few months of exposure and biogas production rate is affected by introducing C60 nanomaterial.
Furthermore, researchers indicated that carbon based nanomaterials such as (reduced) graphene oxide and CNT can facilitate the reduction of recalcitrant pollutants, such as azo dyes (Colunga et al., 2015; Lu et al., 2014; Pereira et al., 2014), nitroaromatic compounds (Li et al., 2016a,b; Wang et al., 2014) and halogenated pollutants (Chen et al., 2014; Toral-S anchez et al., 2018, 2017) under methanogenic condition. It has been reported that, these materials could mediate the redox conversion of recalcitrant pollutants in biological treatment systems by enhancing electron transfer processes (Cervantes et al., 2000; Pereira et al., 2014).

sections.heading: 2.4. Multi-compound nanoparticles
sections.text:
The relatively high density minerals in the form of NPs may cause non-uniform dispersion and agglomeration of NPs in the AD media (Khalil et al., 2017), which could decrease the availability of the elements for microorganisms and weaken the physicochemical interaction between NPs and microorganisms (Nel et al., 2009). A novel approach is to encapsulate or bind multiple compounds in a combined NPs and take advantage of their unique characteristics (Da Silva et al., 2017). Supporting/coating the NPs onto carrier additives to: 1) overcome the inhibitory effects of agglomeration of NPs and 2) strength the contacts between microorganisms and NPs, could be served as an efficient strategy to increase reactivity and performance of NPs (Elreedy et al., 2017). Distributing metal/metal oxide NPs over the support materials (i.e. TiO2, Al2O3, SiO2, zeolite, carbon based materials, etc.) increase the fraction of surface-exposed atoms of NPs, and consequently, increases the reactivity due to their desired dispersion on the surface of the support (Astruc et al., 2005). (2017) concluded that the ratio 2:1 of NZVI to activated carbon as a support was the optimum ratio that caused the maximum nitrate and phosphate removal from aqueous solutions. In another research, Fateminia and Falamaki (2013) studied the effect of freshly NZVI-Cu bimetallic supported on zeolite. The results proved a great advantage of nitrate anions removal from groundwater under un-buffered conditions. The efforts about using multicompound NPs in biogas production processes are summarized in
Table 4.
Amen et al. (2017) studied the effects of various additives, i.e. NZVI, zeolite, NZVI and zeolite mixture, and NZVI coated zeolite (ICZ) particles, on the AD of domestic sludge at mesophilic conditions. Experimental monitoring showed that addition of ICZ initially induced a lag phase before generation of significant biogas volume as a result of ammonia accumulation at the beginning of digestion period. This is due to the fact that high concentration of ammonia (>400mg/L) inhibits specific enzyme reactions. However, in case of using ICZ, after the lag phase the cumulative production increased more than that of the other examined additives, i.e. NZVI, zeolite, NZVI and zeolite mixture. In addition, higher concentration of Fe NPs on the surface of zeolite particles led to an increase in the biogas generation. The high biogas production rate is probably due to the action of ICZ particles (1000mg/L) that dominate the nonuniform dispersion in the digester media, increase the bioavailability and electron transfer interaction between the external additives and microbiome.
Lu et al. (2016) synthesized iron oxide NPs supported on natural zeolite and investigated their effects on the AD of cow manure and rice straw at mesophilic temperature. In the presence of iron oxidezeolite system, the cumulative methane production rate was 74.11% higher than that of the mixture of iron oxide. In addition, when zeolite was used as additive, the cumulative production rate was 373% higher than that of the controlled condition. A rational behind the positive effects can be due to the enhanced activity of methanogens immobilized on the surface of the iron oxide-zeolite system. Zeolite is a non-cytotoxic mineral having a number of channels and pores on its crystalline structure boosting the immobilization of microorganisms (Borja et al., 2007). The coenzyme F420 assay proved a significantly promoted methanogen activity by the addition of the iron oxide zeolite system. This is due to the fact that the iron oxide zeolites nanoparticle is an efficient carrier, i.e. immobilization support, for methanogens. More microorganisms immobilized on the newly designed NPs because of their larger specific surface area. On the other hand, the iron oxide minerals on the surface of the zeolite accelerated the activity of themethanogen microorganisms by accelerating the electron transfer in the methanogenic process and subsequently increasing the concentration of F420 coenzyme. This novel form of NP facilitates the bioavailability and electron catalysis of iron oxides due to the close distance and convenient contact with the immobilized microorganisms. In addition, the outstanding ion exchangeable ability of iron oxide zeolite system ensured a more stable pH due to the great buffering capacity of the system.
Al-Ahmad et al. (2014) investigated the effect of metal NPs (i.e. Fe, Pd, Pt, Ni, Co, Ag, Cu) encapsulated in porous SiO2 matrix on the AD of acetate and glucose at 55 C and concentration of 10 5mol/L. The results showed that, methane production was catalyzed by Ni, Co, Fe and Pt NPs encapsulated in porous SiO2 by transferring more efficiently electrons to acceptors and enhancing the activity of microorganisms. Addition of these compounds to the media during the AD of acetate increased the methane production rate 70, 48, 7 and 6%, respectively. The authors also investigated the effect of the other concentrations of Ni/SiO2 NPs (i.e. 10 4, and 10 6mol/L) and confirmed that the higher concentrations (10 4mol/L) improved the methane production rate. Furthermore, they concluded that
introducing 10 5mol/L of Cu/SiO2 NPs have neither a positive nor negative impact on themethane production rate, while Pd/SiO2 and Ag/SiO2 inhibited methane production rate.
In another research, Beckers et al. (2013) investigated the enhancement effect of 2e3 nm metallic (Pd, Ag and Cu) or metallic oxide (FexOy) NPs, encapsulated in porous SiO2, on hydrogen production from glucose by a Clostridium butyricum strain. Using very low concentrations (10 6mol/L) of Fe2O3/SiO2 NPs in a batch mode increased 38% of hydrogen production and 58% of maximum H2 production rate in comparison with those obtained without NPs or with silica particles only. These results suggest an improvement of the electron transfer through combinations between enzymes and inorganic materials. An enhancement of the H2 production rate confirmed interactions of microorganisms with NPs. The addition of the NPs would improve the bacterial hydrogen production rate through catalysis involving extracellular mediated-molecules. Furthermore, the encapsulation of the NPs in the silica matrix decreases the risk of agglomeration of the active sites. The NPs didn't show an inhibiting effect because the and/or without SiO2). In fact, it is recognized that Ag and Cu behave as antimicrobial elements since they destroy the membrane cells by contact between the microorganism and the NPs (Bagchi et al., 2012; Sotiriou and Pratsinis, 2010). Iron oxide NPs encapsulated in SiO2 caused the highest H2 production rate. A rational to explain this result can derive from the interaction between NPs and bacteria that resulted in a faster hydrogen production rate. Furthermore, since the SiO2 (without NPs) did not show any significant effect, it can be concluded that only the central active site (i.e. the metal or metal oxide NPs) could play a role in the improvement of the hydrogen production. Considering the low concentration of iron oxide NPs, it is suggested that the enhancement of hydrogen production rate with Fe2O3/SiO2 catalysts is related to a catalytic activity working in parallel with the enzymes involved in electron transfer as the hydrogenases, c-cytochromes or/and with extracellular electron mediators. Indeed, the immobilized iron oxide active sites could be used by the bacteria for oxidation/reduction chemical reaction (considering the redox couple Fe2þ/Fe3þ) to help the bacteria transferring faster its electrons without consuming or metabolising the iron when it is added to the medium in a dissolved form. However, considering the small size of the iron oxide NPs (around 3 nm), the surface effect is greatly enhanced and may improve the ability of the NPs to react with the electrons transported by mediators and transfer them efficiently to electron acceptors or eventually protons.
Isfahani et al. (2018) investigated the effect of 5.0 wt% NiOcoated TiO2 NPs on the AD of wheat straw at thermophilic condition. Results showed that addition of different dosages of NiOeTiO2 NPs to batch assays, i.e. 0.252mg of NiOeTiO2/gTS, resulted in up to 13% increased soluble chemical oxygen demand (COD) and up to 67% increase of volatile fatty acids (VFAs) concentration in comparison with control experiments. Methane production rate was increased while no significant increase of final methane production was observed in batch experiments.

sections.heading: 3. Summary and perspectives
sections.text:
Supplementation of inorganic additives in form of nanomaterials caused enhancement in the AD performance because it offers unique physio-chemical properties, i.e. high surface area, increased number of active sites, high reactivity, high specificity, self-assembly, promoted mobility in the AD media, and dispersibility. Furthermore, the stimulating effects of nanomaterials can be related to the cellular uptake of nanomaterials inside the microorganisms and integrating with the metabolic intermediates and key enzyme activity involved in AD processes. All the
nanomaterials used in AD processes were categorized into four groups, namely zero valent metallic NPs, metal oxide NPs, carbonous nanomaterials, and multi-compound NPs. Results clearly indicate that using nanomaterials can be a useful strategy to improve the performance of the AD process. Using multi-functional nanomaterials, that are capable of accomplishing multiple objectives, is a promising method to improve the AD process. The objectives included facilitating direct interspecies electron transfer (DIET), preventing sulfur/ammonia inhibition, controlled nutrient and trace elements supplementation or providing an active substrate for enzyme immobilization.
Fe, Ni, Co, Mo, Se, Cu, Zn are constituent of enzymes/microorganisms and are known to be fundamental trace elements for numerus AD reactions. Depending on type and composition of feedstock, the need for these trace elements is variable. It is crucial to ensure that the proportion of trace elements in AD media is optimal. Deposition of trace elements in form of metal/metal oxide NPs on different supports with optimal proportion is an idea to take advantages of support and deposited materials at a same time, as well as avoiding uneven dispersion of trace elements. Designing multi-functional nanomaterials using above mentioned trace elements (metal/metal oxide) could increase the bioavailability of the trace elements and strengthen the interaction between NPs of trace elements and functional microorganisms (which are required for AD). Actually deposition of metal/metal oxide NPs over the support materials, i.e. carbonous nano structures, TiO2, Al2O3, SiO2, increases the fraction of surface-exposed atoms of NPs, and consequently increases the reactivity of these metals due to desire dispersion of metal/metal oxides on surface of support. Supports should be non-hazardous, cheap and show high surface area, chemical stability as well as capability for dispersing metal/metal oxide NPs highly over the surface. Synthesizing a recyclable support, such as magnetic carriers or supports in form of pellet, could be an ideal choice that make possibility to collect NPs, regenerate them and use continuously in the process.
The perspective could be design, development and fabrication of multi-functional nanomaterial to overcome the bottleneck steps in AD processes using different feedstock. In the future, the following stages should be considered to achieve a novel multi-functional nanomaterial: (1) Deep understanding of the effects of different nanomaterials on each step of the AD process by using model substrates. (2) Fabrication of multi-functional nanomaterials, i.e. deposition of several metal/metal-oxide NPs on supporting materials (3) Tuning the activity of multi-functional nanomaterial via optimization of composition ratios. (4) Assessment of fabricated nanomaterial through application in the presence of different types of substrates.

Addition of electrically conductive materials, to anaerobic digesters is an engineered approach to stimulate DIET and subsequently promote biogas production. NZVI has been widely investigated as a nanoscale zero valent metallic additive in the field of biogas production. Suanon et al. (2017) showed that the application of 100mg/L NZVI (160 nm) in batch bio-digesters enhanced the methane production from sewage sludge up to 25.

(2017) showed that the application of 100mg/L NZVI (160 nm) in batch bio-digesters enhanced the methane production from sewage sludge up to 25.2%. The results were in accordance with previous findings reported in elsewhere (Su et al., 2013; Xu et al., 2004). Su et al. (2013) reported the promotion of biogas and methane production up to 30.

The effects of 9 nm NZVI NPs on the methanogenic archaea during the AD of raw manure (feces and urine) in a batch mode were also investigated by Abdelsalam et al. (2017a, b). They reported that addition of 20mg/L of NZVI NPs to bio-digester under mesophilic temperature stimulates the methanogenic archaea and increases its activity and subsequently increasing biogas and methane production up to 45 and 59%, respectively. On the contrary, Yang et al. (2013) showed that NZVI NPs (55 nm) with a concentration of 1mM (56mg/L) inhibited methanogenesis more than 20% during the AD of sludge.

They showed that the addition of the examined NPs led to reduction of lag phase and increase of biogas and methane production rates. The cumulative amount of biogas and methane production were directly proportional to the concentration of Ni NPs up to 2mg/L the results confirmed that the addition of 0.5, 1 and 2mg/L Ni NPs and 1mg/L NiCl2 to the substrate increased the biogas production by 46, 72, 74 and 44%, respectively. These results are in agreement with those obtained by Demirel and Scherer (2011) who stated that the stimulatory concentrations of Ni for batch cultures of methanogens were in the range of 0.012e5mg/L. Introducing 0.5mg/L Co, 1mg/L of Co NPs, and 1mg/L of CoCl2 increased the biogas production up to 36, 64, and 32% higher than the volume of biogas produced under controlled condition, respectively. Enhancement of biogas and methane production using 1mg/L Co NPs was in accordance with the results obtained by Demirel and Scherer (2011) and Feng et al. (2010) who reported that Co is an important metal for methanogenesis as it acts as metallic enzyme activator.

Abdelsalam et al. (2017a, b) studied the effect of Ni and Co NPs (0.5, 1, and 2mg/L) on the AD of manure at mesophilic conditions. They showed that the addition of the examined NPs led to reduction of lag phase and increase of biogas and methane production rates. The results revealed that Ni and Co NPs have strong biostimulating effects on the methanogenic activity. The cumulative amount of biogas and methane production were directly proportional to the concentration of Ni NPs up to 2mg/L the results confirmed that the addition of 0.5, 1 and 2mg/L Ni NPs and 1mg/L NiCl2 to the substrate increased the biogas production by 46, 72, 74 and 44%, respectively. These results are in agreement with those obtained by Demirel and Scherer (2011) who stated that the stimulatory concentrations of Ni for batch cultures of methanogens were in the range of 0.012e5mg/L. Introducing 0.5mg/L Co, 1mg/L of Co NPs, and 1mg/L of CoCl2 increased the biogas production up to 36, 64, and 32% higher than the volume of biogas produced under controlled condition, respectively. Enhancement of biogas and methane production using 1mg/L Co NPs was in accordance with the results obtained by Demirel and Scherer (2011) and Feng et al. (2010) who reported that Co is an important metal for methanogenesis as it acts as metallic enzyme activator. On the other hand, the addition of Co NPs with concentration more than 1mg/L, i.e. 2mg/L, showed a toxicity effect on the methanogenic archaea which decreased 5% of biogas production and 12.7% of methane, compared to the controlled assays, during 50 days of AD process. The undesired effect of 2mg/L Co NPs on biogas and methane production are in agreement with those reported by Facchin et al. (2013) declaring that the supplementation of excess metals could have a negative effect on acetoclastic methanogenesis or on other metabolic pathways of an AD process.

Based on their results, negatively charged citrate-coated NPs (citrate-Ag NPs) and minimally charged polyvinylpyrrolidone coated Ag NPs (PVPeAg NPs) showed no toxicity and inhibitory effects on biogas production at any concentration. In the case of citrate-Ag NPs, the lack of toxicity might be due to aggregation and subsequent settling which can lower the bioavailability of NPs for the microbiome. The minimum surface charge on PVP-Ag NPs may have resulted in lower attraction between the NPs and the negatively charged bacterial membrane, exhibiting low toxicity. In the developing field of nanotechnology, it is tried to benefit from metal oxide NPs in process of biogas production. The number of reports concerning the toxicity of NPs indicate that addition of natural organic matter (NOM) to the different NPs resulted in lower toxicity to the majority of the organisms (Grillo et al., 2015).
NOM could form complexes with released metal ions and lowering their bioavailability in the media, hence lowering the toxicity (Gao et al., 2012).
In the other scenario the surface charge of NPs could be changed due to bonding with the NOM, changing the interaction with other compounds (Romanello and Cortalezzi, 2013).

Ambuchi et al. (2016) investigated the role of iron oxide NPs (Fe2O3) in the enhancement of the AD performance of granular activated sludge. The results showed that Fe2O3 NPs at a concentration of 750mg/L caused faster utilization of substrate and biogas production rates than the controlled condition. Ambuchi et al. (2016) investigated the role of iron oxide NPs (Fe2O3) in the enhancement of the AD performance of granular activated sludge. The results showed that Fe2O3 NPs at a concentration of 750mg/L caused faster utilization of substrate and biogas production rates than the controlled condition. In their study, microbial community analysis revealed the role of Anaerolineaceae and Longilinea bacteria, predominant bacterial genera in the biodegradation process, could have highly been boosted by NPs. The influence of ZnO NPs on the methane production rate during the AD of waste activated sludge was investigated by Mu et al. (2011). Their results indicated that 1 mg/g-TSS of ZnO NPs had no positive or negative effect on the methane production rate, while 30 and 150 mg/g-TSS of ZnO NPs caused 18.3% and 75.1% inhibition, respectively. The toxic effect of ZnO NPs on themethane production rate was mainly attributed to the release of Zn2þ ion, which inhibited the activities of protease, acetate kinase, and coenzyme F420, leading to inhibition of hydrolysis and methanation steps (Zheng et al., 2015). Zhang et al. (2017) declared that addition of ZnO nanomaterials during the AD of activated sludge increased the accumulation of VFAs.

Ambuchi et al. (2016) investigated the role of iron oxide NPs (Fe2O3) in the enhancement of the AD performance of granular activated sludge. The results showed that Fe2O3 NPs at a concentration of 750mg/L caused faster utilization of substrate and biogas production rates than the controlled condition. In their study, microbial community analysis revealed the role of Anaerolineaceae and Longilinea bacteria, predominant bacterial genera in the biodegradation process, could have highly been boosted by NPs. The influence of ZnO NPs on the methane production rate during the AD of waste activated sludge was investigated by Mu et al. (2011). Their results indicated that 1 mg/g-TSS of ZnO NPs had no positive or negative effect on the methane production rate, while 30 and 150 mg/g-TSS of ZnO NPs caused 18.3% and 75.1% inhibition, respectively. The toxic effect of ZnO NPs on themethane production rate was mainly attributed to the release of Zn2þ ion, which inhibited the activities of protease, acetate kinase, and coenzyme F420, leading to inhibition of hydrolysis and methanation steps (Zheng et al., 2015). Zhang et al. (2017) declared that addition of ZnO nanomaterials during the AD of activated sludge increased the accumulation of VFAs. The promoted VFAs accumulation in the presence of ZnO nanomaterials was due to the slow production and slower consumption rates of VFAs during the AD process. The decrease of production rate of VFAs was mainly contributed to the inhibition of protein hydrolysis by Zn2þ ions. Decrease in biogas and methane production was in agreement with the results obtained by Mu and Chen (2011) that proved the slow consumption of VFAs in the presence of ZnO nanomaterials.

The results showed that the most toxic compounds to anaerobic microorganisms were CuO NPs (30 nm), ZnO NPs (50e70 nm), bulk ZnO and bulk CuO, respectively. It is noteworthy that the biogas production rate increased in the last days of experiment, indicating that the anaerobic bacteria were adapted to the NPs and were able to tolerate in such an environment. Ambuchi et al. (2016) investigated the role of iron oxide NPs (Fe2O3) in the enhancement of the AD performance of granular activated sludge. The results showed that Fe2O3 NPs at a concentration of 750mg/L caused faster utilization of substrate and biogas production rates than the controlled condition. In their study, microbial community analysis revealed the role of Anaerolineaceae and Longilinea bacteria, predominant bacterial genera in the biodegradation process, could have highly been boosted by NPs. The influence of ZnO NPs on the methane production rate during the AD of waste activated sludge was investigated by Mu et al. (2011). Their results indicated that 1 mg/g-TSS of ZnO NPs had no positive or negative effect on the methane production rate, while 30 and 150 mg/g-TSS of ZnO NPs caused 18.3% and 75.1% inhibition, respectively. The toxic effect of ZnO NPs on themethane production rate was mainly attributed to the release of Zn2þ ion, which inhibited the activities of protease, acetate kinase, and coenzyme F420, leading to inhibition of hydrolysis and methanation steps (Zheng et al., 2015). Zhang et al. (2017) declared that addition of ZnO nanomaterials during the AD of activated sludge increased the accumulation of VFAs. The promoted VFAs accumulation in the presence of ZnO nanomaterials was due to the slow production and slower consumption rates of VFAs during the AD process. The decrease of production rate of VFAs was mainly contributed to the inhibition of protein hydrolysis by Zn2þ ions. Decrease in biogas and methane production was in agreement with the results obtained by Mu and Chen (2011) that proved the slow consumption of VFAs in the presence of ZnO nanomaterials. (2013) investigated the inhibitory effect of inorganic oxide NPs (i.e. Al2O3, CeO2, CuO, ZnO, Fe2O3, Mn2O3, SiO2, TiO2) on acetoclastic and hydrogenotrophic methanogenic activities in the AD of granular sludge. The results revealed that CuO and ZnO NPs are highly inhibitory to activity of acetoclastic and hydrogenotrophic methanogens. 62 and 68mg/L of CuO NPs and 87 and 250mg/L of ZnO NPs caused 50% inhibition towards acetoclastic and hydrogenotrophic methanogens, respectively. The inhibition is mainly due to the release of toxic Cu2þ and Zn2þ ions caused by corrosion and dissolution of the NPs. In contrary, methanogens were not inhibited when exposed to high concentrations (1500mg/L) of Al2O3, CeO2, Mn2O3, Fe2O3, SiO2, and TiO2 NPs, suggesting that anaerobic treatment processes could tolerate high concentrations of these types of NPs. The number of reports concerning the toxicity of NPs indicate that addition of natural organic matter (NOM) to the different NPs resulted in lower toxicity to the majority of the organisms (Grillo et al., 2015). NOM could form complexes with released metal ions and lowering their bioavailability in the media, hence lowering the toxicity (Gao et al., 2012). In the other scenario the surface charge of NPs could be changed due to bonding with the NOM, changing the interaction with other compounds (Romanello and Cortalezzi, 2013). Chen et al. (2011) reported using 10mg/L of humic acids (HA), as a model for NOM, in contaminated water with hazardous oxidized pollutants significantly decreased toxicity of NZVI towards gram-negative Escherichia coli and gram-positive Bacillus subtilis.

Amen et al. (2017) studied the effects of various additives, i.

Amen et al. (2017) studied the effects of various additives, i.e. NZVI, zeolite, NZVI and zeolite mixture, and NZVI coated zeolite (ICZ) particles, on the AD of domestic sludge at mesophilic conditions. Experimental monitoring showed that addition of ICZ initially induced a lag phase before generation of significant biogas volume as a result of ammonia accumulation at the beginning of digestion period. This is due to the fact that high concentration of ammonia (>400mg/L) inhibits specific enzyme reactions. However, in case of using ICZ, after the lag phase the cumulative production increased more than that of the other examined additives, i.e. NZVI, zeolite, NZVI and zeolite mixture. In addition, higher concentration of Fe NPs on the surface of zeolite particles led to an increase in the biogas generation. The high biogas production rate is probably due to the action of ICZ particles (1000mg/L) that dominate the nonuniform dispersion in the digester media, increase the bioavailability and electron transfer interaction between the external additives and microbiome. In another research, Beckers et al. (2013) investigated the enhancement effect of 2e3 nm metallic (Pd, Ag and Cu) or metallic oxide (FexOy) NPs, encapsulated in porous SiO2, on hydrogen production from glucose by a Clostridium butyricum strain.

In fact, it is recognized that Ag and Cu behave as antimicrobial elements since they destroy the membrane cells by contact between the microorganism and the NPs (Bagchi et al., 2012; Sotiriou and Pratsinis, 2010). Iron oxide NPs encapsulated in SiO2 caused the highest H2 production rate. A rational to explain this result can derive from the interaction between NPs and bacteria that resulted in a faster hydrogen production rate. Furthermore, since the SiO2 (without NPs) did not show any significant effect, it can be concluded that only the central active site (i.e. the metal or metal oxide NPs) could play a role in the improvement of the hydrogen production. Considering the low concentration of iron oxide NPs, it is suggested that the enhancement of hydrogen production rate with Fe2O3/SiO2 catalysts is related to a catalytic activity working in parallel with the enzymes involved in electron transfer as the hydrogenases, c-cytochromes or/and with extracellular electron mediators. Indeed, the immobilized iron oxide active sites could be used by the bacteria for oxidation/reduction chemical reaction (considering the redox couple Fe2þ/Fe3þ) to help the bacteria transferring faster its electrons without consuming or metabolising the iron when it is added to the medium in a dissolved form. However, considering the small size of the iron oxide NPs (around 3 nm), the surface effect is greatly enhanced and may improve the ability of the NPs to react with the electrons transported by mediators and transfer them efficiently to electron acceptors or eventually protons.
